page.title: 19Heskin Old Hall Farm
page.content: Built about 1800, of stone recovered from the burnt-out Old Hall, the farm has belonged to the Cooper family for three generations. The farm covers 200 acres, and wheat and barley are grown on the whole of it. The farm is fully mechanised, so the farmer does not employ any workers, depending on the other three members of his family to help out. All the grain produced is fed to their 10,000 battery hens. The eggs are graded for size and packed on the farm before being sold. The very old crook barn houses 27 tractors. Five are used on the farm; the rest are vintage models, forming a collection which the farmer hopes to restore. A few pigs are kept, but not as a commercial venture.
